These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

4. Experimental SectionSynthesis of F-Cage: Four batches were run in parallel. To a solution of salicylaldehyde 2c (90.5? mg, 120? ¦Ìmol) in 10? mL THF abs, triamino triptycene 1 (24.0? mg, 80? ¦Ìmol) was added and stirred until a clear solution was formed. 8? mL anhydrous THF and 0.1 m TFA (36? ¦ÌL, 0.045 equiv. relative to 1) in THF abs was added and the mixture was Figure 6. Applicability investigations of F-cage. a) Breakthrough curve of a 10:90 c-C 4F8/N2 mixture with 50% helium as carrier gas (for experimental details see the Experimental Section). b) N 2 isotherms at 77 K (12 point in the typical BET-region) after stirring F-cage in water for 18 h (black), HCl aq (0.1?¡Á 10?3 m) for 24 h (red), or NaOH aq (1 ¡Á 10?3 m) for 24 h (blue). c) Recyclability test of F-cage demonstrated for seven adsorption and desorption cycle of c-C 4F8 at 298?K.

Crystal Growth and Activation: The crystallization of F-cage is described here as a representative procedure. As-synthesized F-cage (1.20?g) was dissolved in dry THF (400?mL, c? = 3?mg mL?1) and filtered through a syringe filter (0.2? ¦Ìm pore). 10?mL of the filtered cage solution each was added to 40 individual snap-lid jars (25? mL, d? = 3? cm). All vials were capped, with caps with 12 pinched holes each and placed in two desiccators with the ground covered with methanol. After vapor diffusion of methanol into the THF cage solutions at room temperature for 21 days, the mother liquors for every vial were removed by a pipette technique and the residual crystals were washed with a methanol/THF mixture (Vmethanol /VTHF? = ?4/1) (3 ¡Á 2?mL) and methanol (2?mL), again by pipette technique. The crystals of the different batches were combined as suspensions, the supernatant solvents were removed and the residual dried at high vacuum (1.2 mbar) for 14 h at room temperature to give pre-activated F-cage (890? mg, 74% efficiency of the crystal growth/activation procedure). Further activation was achieved by drying at a kugelrohr oven at 50 ¡ãC under reduced pressure (3 ¡Á 10?2? mbar) for 14 h. Prior to gas adsorption measurements, the cage crystals were activated again at 40 ¡ãC for 3 h at the outgas station of the gas sorption analyzer and measured directly. The complete removal of enclathrated solvent molecules was verified by 1H NMR spectroscopic as well as TG analyses (see Section S11, Supporting Information) and the persistence of the crystallinity was monitored by optical microscopy along with SEM as well as PXRD and SCXRD (for detailed descriptions, see Section S12 and S13, Supporting Information).

S5  2. Synthetic Procedures  2',5'-Dibutoxy -4,4''-dihydroxy -[1,1':4',1'' -terphenyl] -3,3''-dicarbaldehyde (2a)    In a screw -capped-vessel  salicylaldehyde S1 (3.44 g, 13.9 mmol) and dibromide  S2 (2.00 g, 5.75 mmol) were suspended in THF (40 mL) and an aqueous K 2CO 3 solution (1  M, 10 mL) under argon atmosphere.  5 mol -% tris(dibenzylideneacetone)dipalladium(0) (266 mg, 290 ¦Ìmol) and 10 mol -% tri-tert-butylphosphonium tetrafluoroborate (168 mg, 579 ¦Ìmol) were added to the mixture. The suspension was heated to 80 ¡ãC and stirred for 16 h. After cooling to room temperature, the suspension was poured on water (20 mL), extracted with CH 2Cl2 (3 ¡Á 40 mL) and the combined organic layer was dried over Na 2SO 4. After removal of solvent under reduced pressure, the obtained crude solid was purified by column chromatography (SiO 2, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate = 5:1, Rf  = 0.48) to give 2a as colorless solid  in 54% yield (1.36 g, 3.16  mmol).

S6  Phenyl -1,4-di-magnesiumbromide  (S4)   In a 250 mL three -necked round -bottom flask, magnesium flakes (15.6 g, 640 mmol) were covered with anhydrous THF (70 mL) under argon atmosphere. A solution of dibromobenzene S3 (18.8 g, 79.7  mmol) in anhydrous THF (170 mL) was added in portions under reflu x. After the initiation of the reaction (approx. after added 10 mL of solution) the rest of the of dibromobenzene solution in THF was added dropwise and the resulting mixture was refluxed for additional 3 h to give a THF solution  twofold Grignard reagent S4 which was used without further characterization .

1,4-bis(3,3,4,4,4 -Pentafluorobutyl)benzene (S6)     A 500 mL flask was charged with 1,1,1,2,2 -pentafluoro -4-iodobutane  S5 (45.0 g, 0.16 mol ), CuI (1.87 g, 9.84 mmol) and anhydrous THF (160 mL) under argon and  136 mL of solution of S4 was added dropwise. The resulting mixture was stirred at 50 ¡ãC for 40 h . After quenching  with water  (50 mL) , the THF was removed using a rotary evaporator and the  residual  mixture was extracted with CH 2Cl2 (3 ¡Á 50mL) . The combined organic layer  was dried over MgSO 4 and the solvent removed under reduced pressure . The obtained liquid was purified by column chromatography (SiO 2, petroleum ether, Rf  = 0.35) to give S6 as colorless solid  in 31% yield (based on S3 over two steps) (7.81 g, 21.1 mmol). M.p. = 94 ¡ãC. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä = 7.17 ppm (s, 4H, H -1), 2.91 -2.87 (m, 4H, H -3), 2.39 -2.26 (m, 4H, H -4). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä =137.8 ppm (C-2), 128.8 (C -1), 32.9 (t, J = 21.9 Hz, C -4), 26.3 (t, J = 4.1 Hz, C -3), 115.5 (tq, 1JC-F = 252.1  Hz, 2JC-F = 37.7 Hz, C -5), 119.3 (qt, 1JC-F = 285.3 Hz, 2JC-F = 36.1 Hz, C -6). 19F NMR (283 MHz, CDCl 3): ¦Ä = -85.4 ppm (s, F-6), -118.5 (s, F-5). FT-IR (neat, ATR): ??? = 2958 cm-1 (w), 1519 (w), 1459 (w), 1426 (w), 1351 (m), 1317 (m), 1295 (m), 1282 (m), 1175 (s), 1116 (w), 1059 (s), 979  (s), 961  (s), 861  (m), 801  (m), 764  (m), 692  (s), 607 (m).  MS (EI+):  [M]+: m/z Calcd. for (C 14H12F10+): 370.0799, found 370.0769. Elemental Analysis (%): ( C14H12F10) Calcd. C 45.42, H 3.27, f ound C 45.56, H 3.69.

S7  1,4-Dibromo -2,5-bis(3,3,4,4,4 -pentafluorobutyl)benzene (S7)     S6 (9.00 g, 24.3 mmol ) was added to a mixture of trifluoroacetic acid (120 mL) and concentrated sulfuric acid ( 36 mL ). The mixture was stirred at  60 ¡ãC, and N-bromosuccinimide (NBS) (8.87  g, 49.8 mmol) was added in portions (1.48 g h-1) over 5 h. After stirring for additional  2 hours at 60 ¡ãC, the mixture was cooled to roomtemperature and ice water (500 mL) was added . The resulting suspension was diluted with CH 2Cl2 (500 mL) and  washed with water (100 mL). After removal of solvent under reduced pressure, the crude solid was purified by column chromatography (SiO 2, petroleum) to give S7 as colorless solid  in 78% yield (10.0 g, 18.9 mmol).

4,4''-Dihydroxy -2',5'-bis(3,3,4,4,4 -pentafluorobutyl) -[1,1':4',1'' -terphenyl] -3,3''-dicarbaldehyde (2b)    In a screw -capped vessel salicylaldehyde S1 (2.25 g, 9.07  mmol ) and  dibromide S7 (2.00 g, 3.79 mmol  ) were suspended in THF (32 mL) and an aqueous K 2CO 3 solution (1 M, 8 mL) under argon. 5 mol -% tris(dibenzylideneacetone)dipalladium(0) (173 mg, 189 ¦Ìmol) and 10 mol -% tri-tert-butylphosphonium tetrafluoroborate  (110 mg, 379 ¦Ìmol ) were added and the mixture stirred at 80 ¡ãC for 14 h. After cooling the reaction mixture to room temperature, it was poured on water (20 mL), extracted with CH 2Cl2 (3 ¡Á 50 mL) and the combined organic layer w as dried over MgSO 4. After r emoval of solvent s under reduced pressure, the crude product  was purified by column chromatography (SiO 2, petroleum ether/ethyl acetate/AcOH = 100:20:1, Rf = 0.36) to give 2b as colorless solid in 39% yield (900 mg, 1.47mmol). 4,4''-dihydroxy -2',5'-bis(perfluorobutyl) -[1,1':4',1'' -terphenyl] -3,3''-dicarbaldehyde (2c)    In a screw -capped vessel  alicylaldehyde S1 (1.60 g, 6.45 mmol) and dibromide  S8 (1.80 g, 2.68 mmol) were suspended in THF (32 mL) and K 2CO 3 solution (1  M, 8 mL) under argon. 10 mol -% tris(dibenzylideneacetone)dipalladium(0) (245 mg, 268 ¦Ìmol,) and 20 mol -% tri-tert-butylphosphonium tetrafluoroborate (156 mg, 538 ¦Ìmol,) were added to the mixture  and heated to 80 ¡ãC for 16 h. After cooling to r oom temperature, the suspension was poured on water (40 mL), was extracted with CH 2Cl2 (3 ¡Á 100 mL) and the combined organic layer was dried over Na 2SO 4.

After removal of solvent s under reduced pressure, the obtained crude solid was purified by column chromatography (SiO 2, petroleum ether /CH 2Cl2 = 5:4, Rf = 0.32) to give 2c as colorless solid  in 32% yield (646 mg, 856 ¦Ìmol). M.p. = 216 ¡ãC. 1H NMR  (500 MHz, THF -d8): ¦Ä = 10.99 ppm (s, 2H, H -1), 10.02 (s, 2H, H -8), 7.74 (s, 2H, H -10), 7.69 (d, J = 2.5 Hz, 1H, H-4), 7.52 (dd, J = 8.5, 2.5 Hz, 2H, H -6), 7.04 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H, H -7). 13C NMR  (126 MHz, THF -d8): ¦Ä = 196.4 ppm (C -8), 162.1 (C-2), 142.2 (C -9), 137.7 (C -6), 134.3 (C -4), 134.2(C -10), 130.4 (C -5), 121.2 (C -3), 117.5 (C -7).

H-Cage:    In six individual reactions , triamino triptycene  1 (24.0 mg, 80.0 ¦Ìmol ) and s alicylaldehyde  2a (51.7 mg, 120  ¦Ìmol ) were dissolved each in anhydrous DMF (18 mL) in six 25 mL screw -capped vessel s and 3 mol -% TFA (0.1 M in anhydrous DMF, 24 ¦ÌL) was added to the individual solution s. The mixture s were  stirred at 100 ¡ãC for 3 days. After cooling to room temperature , the reaction mixtures were combined, filtered t hrough syringe filters (0.2 ¦Ìm  pore) and concentrated  to approx.  48 mL by rotary evaporation (5 5 ¡ãC). Methanol (8 0 mL) was added and the  obtained  suspension was stirred for 30 min utes. The orange precipitate was filtered, washed with methanol (4 ¡Á 20 mL ) and dried under high vacuum (1.4  mbar ) for 14 h at room temperature  to give H-cage  as orange solid in 87% yield (370 mg, 208 ¦Ìmol). HF-Cage:   In six individual reactions , triamino triptycene  1 (24.0 mg, 80.0 ¦Ìmol) and salicylaldehyde 2b (73.3 mg, 120 ¦Ìmol) were dissolved each  in anhydrous DMF (18 mL) in six 25 mL screw -capped vessel s and  3 mol -% TFA ( 0.1 M  in anhydrous DMF,  24 ¦ÌL ) was added to the solution s. The mixture s were  stirred at 100  ¡ãC for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature , the reaction mixtures were combined, filtered through syringe filters (0.2 ¦Ìm  pore) and concentrated  to approx.  28 mL by rotary evaporat ion (55 ¡ãC). Methanol (100 mL) was added and the obtained suspension was stirred for 30 minutes. The orange precipitate was filtered, washed with methanol (4 ¡Á 20 mL) and dried under high vacuum (1.4 mbar) for 14 h at room t emperature to obtain  HF-cage  as orange solid  in 69% yield (386 mg, 166 ¦Ìmol). F-Cage:   In four individual reactions , salicylaldehyde 2c (90.5 mg, 120 ¦Ìmol each ) was heated and stirred in anhydrous THF (10 mL ) in four 25 mL screw -capped vessel s until it dissolved . After cooling  to room temperature, triamino triptycene  1 (24.0 mg, 80.0 ¦Ìmol  each ) was added to the individual solution. After complete dissolution , additional  anhydrou s THF (8 mL ) and 4.5 mol-%TFA ( 0.1 M  in anhydrous THF,  36 ¦ÌL,) were  added. The mixture s were  stirred at 85 ¡ãC for 2 days. After cooling to room temperature , the reaction mixtures were combined, filtered through syringe filters (0.2 ¦Ìm  pore) and concentrated to ~22  mL by rotary evaporation .

Methanol (20 mL) was added and the obtained suspension was stirred for 30 minutes. The yellow  precipitate was filtered, washed with methanol ( 3 ¡Á 20 mL) and dried under high vacuum (1.4 mbar) for 14 h at room temperature to give F-cage as light yellow solid in 71% yield (313 mg, 114 ¦Ìmol,).  M.p.: >350 ¡ãC.  1H NMR  (500 MHz, THF -d8): ¦Ä = 13.36 (s, 6H, 9-OH), 9.15 (s, 6H, imine -H-7), 7.83 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 6H, H -5), 7.76 (s, 6H, H -15), 7.56 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 6H, H -2), 7.41 (dd,  J = 8.1 Hz, 2.3 Hz,  6H, H -11), 7.38 (d,  J = 2.3 Hz, 6H, H -13),, 7.24 (dd, J = 7.8, 2.0 Hz, 6H, H -3), 7.03 (d, J = 8.1 Hz, 6H, H -10), 5.72 (s, 2H, bridgehead -H-1), 5.57 (s, 2H, bridgehead -H-6). 13C NMR  (126 MHz, THF -d8): ¦Ä = 162.1 (C -9), 159.7 (C -7), 146.6  (C-5a), 145.3  (C-1a), 144.2 (C -4), 142.7 (C -14), 134.4 (C -15), 134.1 (C -11), 133.6  (C-13), 130.3 (C -16), 129.7 (C-12), 126.0 (C -3), 125.6 (C -2), 119.3 (C -8), 117.2 (C -8), 111.3 (C-5), 56.1 ( bridgehead -C-6), 53.3 ( bridgehead -C-1). Note : Due to strong and multiple 19F-13C-coupling, the signals of the perfluorinated side chains where not visible in 13C-NMR spectra.  19F NMR (471 MHz, THF -d8): ¦Ä = -84.0 (18F , F-20), -105.8 (12F , F-17), -122.7 (12F , F-18), -128.3 (12F , F-19). FT-IR (neat, ATR): ??? = 1628 cm-1 (w), 1610 (w), 1583 (m), 1481 (m), 1429 (w), 1381 (w), 1350 (m), 1288 (m), S12  1277 (m), 1231 (vs), 1202 (s), 1173 (s), 1150 (s), 1132 (vs), 1092 (m), 1057 (w), 1009 (w), 957 (w), 895 (w), 860 (m), 839 (m), 831 (m), 818 (s), 798 (m), 777 (m), 737 (s), 679 (m), 654 (w).

Although some of the crystals appeared cracked, the smaller crystallites still show sharp edges mainly along crystallographic axes. Interestingly, more cracks are apparent for H-cage than for HF-cage and F-cage, which is in line with the strengths of dispersion interactions of the hexameric units of side-chains, as discussed above. Thus, it is assumed that by activation the crystals preferably break along these units. This observed mac-roscopic trend is also reflected by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; Section S13, Supporting Information). Obviously, the dispersion interactions between fluorinated chains are strong enough to fully maintain single crystallinity for the F-cage upon desolvation and activation, allowing to gain decent diffraction data of the apo-host that is having only a slightly enlarged unit cell (Section S7 and S8, Supporting Information).In nitrogen sorption experiments at 77? K as well as argon sorption at 87? K, only fully fluorinated F-cage took up sig-nificant amounts of gases allowing to determine Brunauer¨CEmmett¨CTeller (BET) surface areas of 752 m2 g?1 (N 2) and 728?m2 g?1 (Ar), respectively, while H-cage and HF-cage seemed apparently nonporous under these conditions (Figure? 3g,h). On first glance, this finding is contradictory to the trend of dispersion interaction strength discussed above. However, this permanent porosity is most likely attributed to a gen-eral higher solubility and thus easier diffusion of gases in fluorinated alkanes in comparison to their hydrocarbon ana-logs.

[28] At elevated temperatures of 195?K,?all three cages take up noteworthy and comparable amounts of both nitrogen (H-cage: 0.58? mmol g?1; HF-cage: 0.67? mmol g?1; F-cage: 0.93? mmol g?1) and carbon dioxide (H-cage: 6.63? mmol g?1; HF-cage: 8.92? mmol g?1; F-cage: 8.66? mmol g?1) (see Figure S109, Supporting Information? and Figure? 3i) at 1? bar proving permanent porosity for all three cages. This indicates a kineti-cally hindered adsorption of nitrogen and argon at cryogenic condition for H-cage and HF-cage, which is underlined by pro-nounced hysteresis observed for H-cage and HF-cage and the absence of such for F-cage (Figure? 3i). The BET surface area derived from carbon dioxide adsorption at 195 K of F-cage is with 605 m2 g?1 between the one of H-cage (372? m2 g?1) and HF-cage (653?m2 g?1) (Figure?3j). The similar adsorption prop-erties at higher temperatures are further proven by similar alkane adsorption behaviors of all three cages at 273? K with uptakes of 0.7¨C1.0?wt% (0.46¨C0.61?mmol g¨C1) of methane, 5.6¨C7 .5? wt% (1.50¨C2.49? mmol g?1) of ethane, and 10.5¨C14.6? wt% (2.37¨C3.30?mmol g?1) of propane at 1?bar (see Figures S112¨CS114, Supporting Information). For instance, for F-cage, the propane adsorption corresponds to 9.09?mmol mmol?1 or 9.09 propane molecules per cage compound which resembles a filling of 84% of the cage void (for more details on pore fillings of different gases, see Section S16 and Table S17, Supporting Information).

This is in agree-ment with nitrogen gas sorption analyses at 77?K showing BET surface areas between 684 and 702 m2 g¨C1 that are comparable to the surface area obtained for the material before aqueous treatment (752?m2?g?1). Furthermore, the recyclability of F-cage was investigated with seven subsequent adsorption and desorp-tion cycles for c-C4F8 exemplarily (Figure?6c). It has to be noted that the material was stored for 204 days under ambient atmos-phere between cycles 1 and 2 and the uptakes of c-C4F8 were all in a range of 99¨C112% (cycle 1 was set to 100%) demonstrating the potential recyclability of F-cage in these kind of separations.

Both, 1H- and 19F-NMR measurements proof the structural integrity of F-cage  after water, acid and base  treatment (Figures S 302 and S30 3) by similar spectra in comparison to the ones before treatment . TG A-analyses (Figure 30 4) indicates no residual water in the pores by a plateau up to the decomposition temperature (~420  ¡ãC). Investigations by 12 -point (the points were choosen in the typical BET -region between  P/P 0 = 0.01-0.1) N2 adsorption  isotherms at 77 K (Figure 6b in the main text ) and corresponding BET anal ysis shows the surface area of 684 m2 g-1(after water treatment) , 700  m2 g-1(after acid treatment)  and 702  m2 g-1(after base treatment) , which are in accordance to the results of the as -crystallized material (see above) and proves the water stability of F-cage .

General Remarks   Commercially available reagents were obtained from Chempur, Fisher Scientific, abcr, Alfa Aesar, Sigma -Aldrich or VWR and have been used without further purification unless otherwise mentioned. 2,7,14 -triaminotriptycene 1 was synthesized according to a pro cedure reported in literature.[S1] 2-Hydroxy -5-(4,4,5,5 -tetramethyl -1,3,2 -dioxaborolan -2-yl)benzaldehyde S1, 1,4 -dibromo -2,5-dibutyl -benzene S2 and 1,4 -dibromo -2,5-bis(perfluorobutyl)benzene  S8 have been  synthesized according to a procedure s reported in li terature.[S2] Thin layer chromatography was performed with POLYGRAM? SIL G/UV254 gel plates by Macherey -Nagel. Detection was accomplished using UV -light (254 nm).  Flash column chromatography was performed on silica gel from Macherey -Nagel  (particle size: 0 .040-0.063 mm) using petroleum ether, dichloromethane , ethyl acetate  or acetic acid  and their mixtures as eluents . Melting points (not corrected) were measured with a B¨¹chi B-540 m elting point analyzer . NMR spectra were taken on a Bruker DRX 300 (300 MHz), Bruker Avance 300 III (300 MHz), Bruker Avance III 400 (400 MHz) , Bruker Avance III 500 (5 00 MHz)  and Bruker Avance III 700 (7 00 MHz) spectrometer.
